1.text: These also are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.

2.text: It is the glory of God to conceal a thing: but the glory of kings is to search out a matter.

3.text: The heaven for height, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings is unsearchable.

4.text: Take away the dross from the silver, and there cometh forth a vessel for the finer:

5.text: Take away the wicked from before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.

6.text: Put not thyself forward in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great men:

7.text: For better is it that it be said unto thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince, whom thine eyes have seen.

8.text: Go not forth hastily to strive, lest thou know not what to do in the end thereof, when thy neighbour hath put thee to shame.

9.text: Debate thy cause with thy neighbour himself, and disclose not the secret of another:

10.text: Lest he that heareth it revile thee, and thine infamy turn not away.

11.text: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in baskets of silver.

12.text: As an earring of gold, and an ornament of fine gold, so is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.

13.text: As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to them that send him; for he refresheth the soul of his masters.

14.text: As clouds and wind without rain, so is he that boasteth himself of his gifts falsely.

15.text: By long forbearing is a ruler persuaded, and a soft tongue breaketh the bone.

16.text: Hast thou found honey? eat so much as is sufficient for thee; lest thou be filled therewith, and vomit it.

17.text: Let thy foot be seldom in thy neighbourâ€™s house; lest he be weary of thee, and hate thee.

18.text: A man that beareth false witness against his neighbour is a maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow.

19.text: Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble is like a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.

20.text: As one that taketh off a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon nitre, so is he that singeth songs to an heavy heart.

21.text: If thine enemy be hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he be thirsty, give him water to drink:

22.text: For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the LORD shall reward thee.

23.text: The north wind bringeth forth rain: so doth a backbiting tongue an angry countenance.

24.text: It is better to dwell in the comer of the housetop, than with a contentious woman in a wide house.

25.text: As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country.

26.text: As a troubled fountain, and a corrupted spring, so is a righteous man that giveth way before the wicked.

27.text: It is not good to eat much honey: so for men to search out their own glory is not glory.

28.text: He whose spirit is without restraint is like a city that is broken down and hath no wall.
